gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: European Petroleum Survey Group (EPSG) Geodetic Parameter Registry
TERN OzFlux Adelaide River Tower Site

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: School of Environment and Life Sciences

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Ecosystem flux data from the Adelaide River site, Northern Territory.The Adelaide River flux station was located approximately 10.5km south east of Bachelor, Northern Territory. The flux tower site was classified as Savanna dominated by Eucalyptus tectifica and Planchonia careya.Elevation of the site was close to 90m and mean annual precipitation at a nearby Bureau of Meteorology site is 1730mm. Maximum temperatures range from 31.4Â°C (in June) to 36.8Â°C (in October) while minimum temperatures range from 16.2Â°C (in July) to 25.1Â°C (in December). Maximum temperature vary seasonally by approximately 5.4Â°C and minimum temperatures vary by approximately 8.9Â°C.The instrument mast was 15 meters tall. Heat, water vapour and carbon dioxide measurements were taken using the open-path eddy flux technique. Temperature, humidity, wind speed, wind direction, rainfall, incoming and reflected shortwave radiation and net radiation were measured above the canopy. Soil heat fluxes are measured and soil moisture content was gathered using time domain reflectometry.The site was established in November 2007 and was managed by Monash University and Charles Darwin University until it was decommissioned in May 2009.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Jason Beringer (2013 ) Adelaide River OzFlux tower site OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14228

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Adelaide River OzFlux Site, Northern Territory, Australia

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: The Adelaide River flux station was part of the Australia Flux Tower network (OzFlux) and the international FLUXNET

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: An introduction to the Australian and New Zealand flux tower network â€“ OzFlux

gmd:code.gco:CharacterString: TERN OzFlux Gingin Tower Data Service

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This service provides access to ecosystem flux data from Gingin in Western Australia. The site is is located in native Banksia woodland on the Swan Coastal Plain about 70km north of Perth.

gmd:metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19115.1:2015 Geographic information - Metadata â€“ Fundamentals

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: European Petroleum Survey Group (EPSG) Geodetic Parameter Registry
TERN OzFlux Great Western Woodlands Tower Site

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The Great Western Woodlands (GWW) comprise a 16 million hectare mosaic of temperate woodland, shrubland and mallee vegetation in south-west WA. The region is extraordinary in that it has remained relatively intact since European settlement, owing to the variable rainfall and lack of readily accessible groundwater.The woodland component is globally unique in that nowhere else do woodlands occur at as little as 220 mm mean annual rainfall. Further, other temperate woodlands around the world have typically become highly fragmented and degraded through agricultural use.The flux site is located in Salmon gum (Eucalyptus salmonophloia) woodland in the northern part of the Great Western Woodlands at mean annual rainfall of c. 240 mm.The site was established in December 2012. It is located on Credo Station, 110km NNW of Kalgoorlie, WA, and is managed by the CSIRO Land and Water Flagship external link (Floreat).

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The flux and supersite work towards building a process-based understanding of semi-arid woodlands to inform management and climate adaptation in the Great Western Woodlands and climate-resilient restoration in the adjacent WA wheatbelt.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Craig Macfarlane (2013 ) Great Western Woodlands OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14226

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Great Western Woodlands, Credo Station, Western Australia

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: Craig Macfarlane (2013 ) Great Western Woodlands OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14226

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: European Petroleum Survey Group (EPSG) Geodetic Parameter Registry
TERN OzFlux Riggs Creek Tower Site

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The Riggs Creek flux station is located in Goulburn-Broken catchment in North-Eastern Victoria. The flux tower site is located within an area of dryland agriculture. The surrounding area is dominated by broadacre farming practices. The vegetation cover is predominantly pasture. Elevation of the site is close to 152m and mean annual precipitation at a nearby Bereau of Meteorology site measures 650mm.Maximum temperatures range from 12.3Â°C (in July) to 29.7Â°C (in February), while minimum temperatures range from 10.4Â°C (in July) to 26.8Â°C (in February).The instrument mast is 4 meters tall. Heat, water vapour and carbon dioxide measurements are taken using the open-path eddy flux technique. Temperature, humidity, wind speed, wind direction, rainfall and net radiation are measured. Soil heat fluxes are measured and soil moisture content is gathered using time domain reflectometry.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The purpose of the Riggs Creek Flux Station was to: Monitor and determine the balance of environmental demands for water yields, agricultural productivity, carbon storage and biodiversity within a catchment landscape. Provide information for other projects (i.e. The Carbon Project) which seeks to establish a modelling tool for carbon and water fluxes across various land use types, in order to benefit land management practices in the Goulburn-Broken catchment region.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Jason Beringer (2014) Riggs Creek OzFlux tower site OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14246

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: Jason Beringer (2014 ) Riggs Creek OzFlux Tower Site OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14246

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: European Petroleum Survey Group (EPSG) Geodetic Parameter Registry
TERN OzFlux Fogg Dam Tower Site

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: School of Environment and Life Sciences

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The Fogg Dam flux station was located approximately 6km east of Black Jungle, Northern Territory. It was established in February 2006 and decommissioned in September 2008. It was managed by Monash University and Charles Darwin University.The site was situated within a wetland that flooded seasonally. The principle vegetation was Oryza rufipogon, Pseudoraphis spinescens and Eleocharis dulcis. The elevation was approximately 4m, with a neighbouring Bureau of Meteorology station recording 1411mm mean annual precipitation.Maximum temperatures ranged from 31.3Â°C (in June and July) to 35.6Â°C (in October), while minimum temperatures ranged from 14.9Â°C (in July) to 23.9Â°C (in December and February). Maximum temperatures varied on a seasonal basis by approximately 4.3Â°C and minimum temperatures by 9.0Â°C.The instrument mast was 15m tall. Heat, water vapour and carbon dioxide measurements are taken using the open-path eddy flux technique. Temperature, humidity, wind speed, wind direction, rainfall, incoming and reflected shortwave radiation and net radiation were measured above the canopy. Soil heat fluxes were measured and soil moisture content was gathered using time domain reflectometry.Ancillary measurements taken at the site include LAI, leaf-scale physiological properties (gas exchange, leaf isotope ratios, N and chlorophyll concentrations), vegetation optical properties and soil physical properties. Airborne based remote sensing (Lidar and hyperspectral measurements) was carried out across the transect in September 2008.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The primary purpose of the Fogg Dam flux station was to: Provide information as part of a larger network of flux towers established along the North Australian Tropical Transect (NATT) gradient, which extends ~1000km south from Darwin 12.5Â° S. The towers provide flux data across the savanna's heterogeneous 'top end' ecosystems including open forest savanna, open savanna woodland and seasonally inundated floodplains. Examine spatial patterns and processes of land-surface-atmosphere exchanges (radiation, heat, moisture, CO2 and other trace gasses) across scales from leaf to landscape scales within Australian savannas. Determine the climate and ecosystem characteristics (physical structure, species composition, physiological function) that drive spatial and temporal variations of carbon, water and energy fluxes from north Australian savanna. Determine if fluxes of carbon, water vapour and heat over the various ecosystems as derived from the various measurement techniques can be combined to form a comprehensive and consistent estimate of the regional fluxes and budgets across the landscape.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Jason Beringer (2008) Fogg Dam OzFlux tower site OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14233

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: An introduction to the Australian and New Zealand flux tower network â€“ OzFlux

TERN OzFlux Dry River Tower Site

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: School of Environment and Life Sciences

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The Dry River flux station is located approximately 89km south of Katherine, Northern Territory. The site was established in 2008 and is managed by The University of Western Australia and Charles Darwin University.The flux tower site is classified as open forest savanna. The overstory is co-dominated by tree species E. tetrodonta, E. dichromophloia, C. terminalis, Sorghum intrans, S. plumosum, Themeda triandra and Chrysopogon fallax, with canopy height averaging 12.3m.Elevation of the site is close to 175m and mean annual precipitation from a nearby Bureau of Meteorology site measures 895.3mm.Maximum temperatures range from 29.1Â°C (in June) to 37.6Â°C (in July), while minimum temperatures range from 14.6Â°C (in July) to 24.8Â°C (in November). Maximum temperatures vary seasonally by 8.5Â°C and minimum by 10.2Â°C.The instrument mast is 15 meters tall. Heat, water vapour and carbon dioxide measurements are taken using the open-path eddy flux technique. Temperature, humidity, wind speed, wind direction, rainfall, incoming and reflected shortwave radiation and net radiation are measured above the canopy. Soil heat fluxes are measured and soil moisture content is gathered using time domain reflectometry.Ancillary measurements taken at the site include LAI, leaf-scale physiological properties (gas exchange, leaf isotope ratios, N and chlorophyll concentrations), vegetation optical properties and soil physical properties. Airborne based remote sensing (Lidar and hyperspectral measurements) was carried out across the transect in September 2008.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The primary purpose of the Dry River Flux Station is to: Provide information as part of a larger network of flux towers established along the North Australian Tropical Transect (NATT) gradient, which extends ~1000 km south from Darwin 12.5Â°S. The towers provide flux data across the savannaâ€™s heterogeneous â€˜top endâ€™ ecosystems including open forest savanna, open savanna woodland and seasonally inundated floodplains. Examine spatial patterns and processes of land-surface-atmosphere exchanges (radiation, heat, moisture, CO2 and other trace gasses) across scales from leaf to landscape scales within Australian savannas. Determine the climate and ecosystem characteristics (physical structure, species composition, physiological function) that drive spatial and temporal variations of carbon, water and energy fluxes from north Australian savanna. Determine if fluxes of carbon, water vapour and heat over the various ecosystems as derived from the various measurement techniques can be combined to form a comprehensive and consistent estimate of the regional fluxes and budgets across the landscape.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Jason Beringer (2013 ) Dry River OzFlux tower site OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14229

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: Jason Beringer (2013 ) Dry River OzFlux tower site OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14229

TERN OzFlux Sturt Plains Tower Site

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: School of Environment and Life Sciences

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The Sturt Plains flux station is located approximately 280km north of Tennant Creek, Northern Territory. It was established in August 2008 and is managed by Monash University external and Charles Darwin University. The Sturt Plains OzFlux Site is located on a low lying plain dominated by Mitchell Grass (gen. Astrebla). Elevation of the site is close to 250m and mean annual precipitation at a nearby Bureau of Meteorology site is 640mm.Maximum temperatures range from 28.4Â°C (in June/ July) to 39.1Â°C (in December), while minimum temperatures range from 11.2Â°C (in July) to 24.4Â°C (in December).The instrument mast is 5 meters tall. Heat, water vapour and carbon dioxide measurements are taken using the open-path eddy flux technique. Temperature, humidity, wind speed, wind direction, rainfall and net radiation are measured. Soil heat fluxes are measured and soil moisture content is gathered using time domain reflectometry.Ancillary measurements taken at the site include LAI, leaf-scale physiological properties (gas exchange, leaf isotope ratios, N and chlorophyll concentrations), vegetation optical properties and soil physical properties. Airborne based remote sensing (Lidar and hyperspectral measurements) was carried out across the transect in September 2008.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The purpose of the Sturt Plains Flux Station is to: Provide information as part of a larger network of flux towers established along the North Australian Tropical Transect (NATT) gradient, which extends ~1000km south from Darwin 12.5Â°S. The towers provide flux data across the savannaâ€™s heterogeneous â€˜top endâ€™ ecosystems including open forest savanna, open savanna woodland and seasonally inundated floodplains. Examine spatial patterns and processes of land-surface-atmosphere exchanges (radiation, heat, moisture, CO2 and other trace gasses) across scales from leaf to landscape scales within Australian savannas. Determine the climate and ecosystem characteristics (physical structure, species composition, physiological function) that drive spatial and temporal variations of carbon, water and energy fluxes from north Australian savanna. Determine if fluxes of carbon, water vapour and heat over the various ecosystems as derived from the various measurement techniques can be combined to form a comprehensive and consistent estimate of the regional fluxes and budgets across the landscape. Provide long-term consistent observations of energy, carbon and water exchange between the atmosphere and the â€˜top endâ€™ grassland.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Jason Beringer (2013 ) Sturt Plains OzFlux tower site OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14230

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Sturt Plains OzFlux Site, Northern Territory

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: Jason Beringer (2013 ) Sturt Plains OzFlux tower site OzFlux: Australian and New Zealand Flux Research and Monitoring hdl: 102.100.100/14230
